testimony: Chairperson, the next applicant is Timothy Stals Mazibuko.  He is the fifth name on the list.
Mr Mazibuko, what language are you going to speak?
Your full names are Timothy Stals Mazibuko?

Thank you Chairperson.  Mr Mazibuko, you have completed and signed a Form 1, which form appears on page 107 of the bundle?  I want you to identify your signature on the last page of Form 1, on page 109?  Is that your signature?
It is stated on this form that you were born in Sebokeng, is that correct?
You elected to speak Sotho, but are you a Zulu person or not?
Are you a member of the Inkatha Freedom Party?

You indicated to me that there is something not correct of this Form 1 and you indicated that at paragraph 11(b) this statement as contained there, is not entirely correct.
	I am going to tell you what is written here, then you must just tell me what is incorrect.  An order was given by the leaders of the IFP staying in the kwaMadala hostel, that Boipatong should be attacked.  Orders were given on the 10th and 17th of June 1992, the leaders were Mkhize and Qunchu.
	You are not entirely happy with what is stated there, can you just indicate what is your complaint?
My problem is that there was a meeting on the 10th, the 10th of June.
According to your recollection, did you go to a meeting on the 10th, where it was discussed that Boipatong should be attacked or not?
When this thing was discussed on the 10th, I was not present.
When was the first time for you personally to become aware that Boipatong was going to be attacked?
I knew firstly on the 17th of June.

I want to refer you to the Annexure to Form 1.  Do you agree with the contents of this document as was discussed with you before you gave evidence?
	Just to make it clear, this document contains some of the answers from Form 1 which there was not enough space actually, to give a full answer, and the answer is contained in this Annexure.  Do you admit the contents of that answers?

Then I want to refer you to a request for further particulars and your answers thereto, that is on page 112 and further.  These answers was - you went through the answers again, do you stand by those answers that you gave?
And lastly, your affidavit on page 116 to 118, do you stand by the affidavit as contained in this document?
Is that your signature on page 118?
Just a few other aspects, you indicated that you lived in Sebokeng.
How come did you leave Sebokeng to go and stay in kwaMadala hostel?
There was a fight between myself and fellow comrades.
Why do you say fellow comrades?
I used to visit a certain friend called Mtana in Sebokeng, he was a member of the IFP from the township.
During the period that you stayed in Sebokeng, were you an IFP supporter or not?
I was not a supporter of any political organisation at that time.
Just tell the Committee more about the problems that you had to deal with in Sebokeng?
In 1992 I was shot in Sebokeng, shot by comrades.
Could you stay in the hospital for the period to recover?
No, I did not stay in the hospital.
Why did you run from the hospital?
My life was in danger in the hospital.
After you left the hospital, where did you go to?
Approximately when did you arrive at kwaMadala hostel?
That is 1992, I think it was between January and April.  I don't remember the exact date.
You indicated earlier that you are an IFP supporter, when did you become an IFP supporter?
After I ran from the hospital, I went to Madala hostel and I joined the IFP.
You also indicated that the first time you heard that there would be an attack on Boipatong, was on the 17th of June.  How did it come that you became aware?
Who told you at the stadium that Boipatong would be attacked?
When I arrived at the stadium, Mkhize was giving a speech.
Now were you prepared to go along to Boipatong, to attack the people there?
Why were you prepared to go to Boipatong to kill people?
I wanted to pay a revenge for what they did to me.
During that period, could you move freely out of the hostel, in the townships, or not?
No, I could not move freely in the township.
I was afraid that they would burn me.
Did you take a weapon to Boipatong?
What kind of weapon did you take?
I had an iron bar and a knopkierie.
We have already heard that there was initially one group, but later on two groups, do you agree with that?  That is two groups in Boipatong consisting out of attackers?
When you went to Boipatong, what was your idea, what would happen in Boipatong?
We were going to attack and kill members of the Self Defence Unit.
Can you briefly describe what happened in Boipatong when you arrived there?
Before we entered Boipatong, we sat under the tree, then we divided ourselves into two groups.
We entered in the last street.
Yes, I want you to continue with what happened in Boipatong.

When we entered in that street, that is where we had a barricade next to a house, in front of that, on the other side of the tank, there were a group of people.
	I thought those were members of the Self Defence Unit because they were of our age.  After that, we directed fire to them.
Could you see who was firing?
The one who was next to me, shooting, was Doctor.
What kind of firearm did he use?
Did you see anybody else firing shots?
What kind of firearm did he have with him?
What happened when those shots were fired in the direction of the Self Defence Unit?
Others entered the houses nearby, others ran on the street.  Then we ran after them, those who were in the houses, and others followed those who ran through the street.
Personally, what did you do whilst you were moving through the streets of Boipatong?
I was not able to catch one of them, we entered in one yard and we broke the window panes.
Apart from that one house, did you break windows at other houses?
Yes, the others continued to break windows in other houses.
Can you tell the Committee what else did you do?

After I broke those windows, there was a house on the corner which I opened the door.  After I had opened that door, a group of people entered that house.
	Whilst they were inside the house and whilst I was continuing breaking the windows, one person burnt a blanket which was inside the house.  I took that blanket and threw it inside the house.  Whilst we were breaking the windows of that house, I jumped the (indistinct) and entered in another big house next door.
	I broke the windows, the big window panes.
Did you enter the house or did you enter the yard?
I only broke the windows, I never entered that house.

When people entered that house, others took TV's, there was one who was scared to take the TV, the big TV.  The person who picked up the big TV, was a little big scared and put it down, then I took it.
Do you know the name of that person?
No, I was not able to identify that person.
At this point, you were at the hostel at that stage, since approximately January to April 1992, did you know many people in the hostel?
Yes, there were people I knew, and many of them were those who came from the township.
And do you know the names of all the people in the hostel or not?
No, I don't know them all.
In any event, you were telling that you then received a TV from this person.  What did you do with the TV?
When we left Boipatong, then we proceeded to Madala hostel, we saw police vans.  Then I put it down, because I was scared that I would be arrested.
Can you give an indication, where did you see the police vans that you say?
Those cars we used to call them suitcases, and they belonged to the SADF.
But where, where did you see that vehicle or vehicles?
They came from the direction of between Tserela and as if they were going towards Vanderbijlpark, and they turned at the robot.
The robot that you refer to, is that the robot at the intersection of Nobel Boulevard and Frikkie Meyer Boulevard?
Whilst you were in Boipatong itself, did you witness any killing of any person?
No, I never saw any person being killed inside Boipatong.
Did you take the same route back to the hostel which you took when you went there?
No, we never used the same route when we returned.
When you went to the hostel, did you still have that TV with you or not?
I left it behind.  I held that iron bar which I had when I went inside Boipatong.
When you got to the hostel, what did you do?
I went straight to my room.
When did you hear for the first time that many people were killed and injured?
I heard the following day, in the morning.
Do you know anything of loot being burnt after the attack in the kwaMadala hostel?
What do you know about that?
It was Richard, that is Richard, Matanda and Mkhize, those who were going around the rooms.
The Mkhize you refer to in your statement, is that Bhekinkosi Mkhize?
Do you know if he personally got something out of a room which he burnt, or not?
Matanda and Richard, did you see them placing anything on a fire?
Apart from the military vehicle that you referred to earlier on in your evidence, did you see any other military or police vehicles during the course of the attack?
No, I did not see any cars.
Do you know a person by the name of Andries Matanzima Nosenga?
Where do you know him from?
I knew him from Madala hostel.
Do you know in which room he stayed in the hostel?
When was the first time for you to see him in the hostel?
It was after the attack of Boipatong, but I don't remember the month or the day or the date.
Prior to the attack, did you know or did you meet Mr Matanzima in the township whilst you were still staying there?
I started knowing him after the attack or the massacre, I think it was after a week.
The allegation has been made that he was a sort of leader of a hitsquad.  What is your comments on that?
No, I know nothing about the hitsquad.
Can I take from that that you were also never a member of any hitsquad?
Yes.  I have never been a member of a hitsquad.
Do you know Prince Vanana Zulu?
During the attack or just prior to the attack, did you see him at the hostel or not?
No, I did not see him.
Were you a member of the Youth Brigade?
If you can just bear with me.   Do you know a structure which is called the AmaButho which operated in the hostel?
Who was the leader of the AmaButho according to you?
The leader I usually saw is Mr Mkhize.
Just prior, just before the attack when you were still at the stadium, did you see Damara Qunchu?
Do you know if he was a leader of any kind?

I've got no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR STRYDOM
Thank you Mr Strydom.  Adv Pretorius, do you have any questions?
Victor Keswa, was he there on the 17th of June?
I know because we used to go and visit him in Vanderbijl in the cells or in prison.
You say there were two groups of attackers in Boipatong.  Can you tell us how big the group was more or less, how many people it consisted of, the big group?
Will you please repeat your question?
How big was the group of the AmaButho going to Boipatong, how many people did it consist of?
Approximately we could have been 200 to 300.
The trouble you had in the township, you say where the SDU shot you.
Sorry, can you just repeat the figure, we just didn't catch it very clearly on the interpretation.
You say you left Sebokeng because you were shot by the comrades.  Who were in charge of the comrades in Sebokeng, which organisation or didn't they belong to an organisation?
Were the comrades and the SDU's the same people?
To my understanding, I think it means the same people.
Did you ever attend a meeting during that week from the 10th until the 18th of June, where Themba Khoza addressed the residents of kwaMadala?

I have no further questions, thank you Chair.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS PRETORIUS
You were asked whether, you talked about two groups that went into Boipatong?
And then you gave the figure of approximately 200 to 300 persons.
Was that an estimate of persons in one group?
May it please you Mr Chairman.  Can you give an estimate of when the group entered Boipatong, what time was that more or less to start the attack?
Can't you estimate at all, do you know if it was late in the evening, near midnight, later?
Well, it was not yet midnight.

You say that you saw, your testimony was that you saw police vans, and because of this you put the TV down, because you were scared that you were going to be arrested?  Do I make the correct deduction that when you saw this police van that you mentioned, that you were in the open veld between Boipatong and Frikkie Meyer Boulevard?
Can you estimate how far you were from this police van?
It was quite a distance.  Let me explain this, I said we saw military vans, not the police vans.
It was translated as police vans, are you saying that it was interpreted incorrectly just now when you testified?

Sorry Mr Da Silva, he did correct it.  He spoke about, he used some unusual term, suitcases.  He said these vans were SADF vehicles, we used to call them suitcases, they were coming from Tserela towards Vanderbijl.

I would like to clarify this aspect, because the actual evidence was we saw police vans, I put it down because I thought I was going to be arrested.  They are suitcases of the SADF and I would like the witness to clarify that.
That was a mistake from the interpretation not the witness.
The Interpreter is saying that was his mistake.
I understand sir, thank you.  In regard to the distance, can you estimate how far you were when you saw this vehicle?
I think it can be a distance from this wall to the back of the hall there.
Mr Chairman, that is approximately 30 meters I would estimate, 30 meters.  I can measure that tomorrow.
Unless something turns on the distance?
To the extreme that it may be necessary, just pace the distance roughly and let us know for the record tomorrow.
I will do so Mr Chairman.
You described this or let me clarify this aspect, your testimony was that you saw suitcases, your testimony interpreted incorrectly was police vans.  Did you see one vehicle or more than one vehicle?
I didn't hear the figure, please repeat it.

Yes, I can describe them.  They are brown vehicles.  When it is facing you, you only see the driver, so the people who are sitting at the back, you only see their heads and their hats.
	There is a big iron on top of it, that is why we refer to it as a suitcase.
And you are quite sure you saw three vehicles?
Were all three vehicles as you describe them, suitcases?
Did you ask him whether all three vehicles were in suitcases?
I will follow that up Mr Chairman.  The vehicles that you saw, were all three vehicles as you describe them, suitcases?
All of them were suitcases.  We used to call them suitcases.
And you mention suitcases because of this iron bar on top, is that right?
Now you know the difference between a military vehicle and a police vehicle?  At that stage my information was that police vehicles were painted yellow or green or camouflage, were you aware of that?
Yes, I am aware of that.
So after you saw these vehicles, you put down the TV and then what did you do?
Then I joined the group and then we crossed over the road.  We were all rushing, we only wanted to cross over the road, so that we can be near our place.
To join the group, did you move away from these vehicles, towards the group, is that what you are saying?

They were facing the road that is moving towards Vanderbiljpark, so we were just passing in front of those vehicles.
	After they had turned at the robot, they were moving with a slow pace, so we managed to cross over the road in front of them.
So, the road that you crossed was Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, is that correct?
Well, I don't know the name of that road, but it is the road that moves from the garage towards Vanderbijlpark.
Do I understand your evidence to be that when you saw these vehicles on your version, that they were on the same road as you crossed, the group crossed?
So the first time you saw these vehicles, on your version, these vehicles were on this road, and then you crossed in front of them, crossing Frikkie Meyer Boulevard?
So where did you leave the TV?
I left the TV at the open veld before the crossed the road.
Do you know a gentleman by the name of Daniel Mabote or Themba Mabote?
Was he part of the group that perpetrated the attack on Boipatong?
Do you remember him being in the group when you gathered in the veld?
Do you remember if he was armed?
He was armed with a small gun.
Were you quite close to him when you were in the group in the veld, when you were gathering in the veld?
From when we entered Boipatong, I was always next to a person armed with a gun.  Even when we returned, I was always next to Themba Mabote because he had a gun.
At the criminal trial you heard the evidence of a Mr Holi Bajozi, do you recall that?
Yes, I heard his evidence but I don't remember what he said.
With reference to Mr Themba Mabote, he testified that Mr Themba Mabote fired a gun in the direction of a Defence Force vehicle, do you recall that?
So you recall that when Mr Mabote saw the Defence Force vehicle, that he actually fired in the direction of the Defence Force vehicle?
And he was pointing his firearm at the Defence Force vehicle?
And how many times did he fire his firearm?
Even though I do not remember, but he ... (tape ends) ... that is correct.
It stands to reason, he also thought he was going to be arrested, and that is why he started firing at the Defence Force vehicle, is that not so?
Well, I don't know why he fired at the military vehicles.
But he must have had a similar fear that you had, he thought he was going to be arrested, that is why he fired?  Do you agree with that?
Well, I don't want to agree, what I can say is that I don't know.
Yes, but you say he fired more than once, you were standing next to him?  Is that correct?
After you crossed Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, is it correct that between kwaMadala hostel and Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, on the eastern side of Frikkie Meyer Boulevard there is a marsh, do you know that?

There was an affidavit handed in, it is Exhibit L earlier in this enquiry, and it is in fact two affidavits by Security personnel of ISCOR, if I remember correctly their affidavit is that they arrested a person whose legs were wet up until the knees.  Is that possible because you crossed this marsh that you would have got wet in crossing the marsh?
Well, where we crossed on our way from Boipatong, there is a footpath, there were no water.
How did you enter kwaMadala hostel?
On our return from Boipatong, we passed the ISCOR place surrounded by the trees, and then we moved on the other side of the bridge towards kwaMadala hostel.
Weren't there people hiding in the marsh from the Defence Force vehicles?  Are you aware of that, was there any person which formed part of your group, that were hiding in the marsh?
No, I heard about that in court, I don't know.
Is it not correct that part of the group entered kwaMadala through a hole in the fence in kwaMadala, do you know about that?

The first time I heard about that, was in court.  What I remember is that we returned, using the same way that we used when we went to Boipatong.
	The first time I heard about people who damaged the fence, I heard about it in court for the first time.  I don't know.
So did you not use this hole in the fence to enter kwaMadala?
No, we did not use the fence.
You say you put the TV down because you were scared of being arrested by the Defence Force vehicles.  Did they normally arrest people, what was your experience?
Since during the times of the riots in the township, they used to arrest people.
So you were expecting them to arrest you, you weren't expecting them to cooperate with you, is that correct?
If they had been cooperating with you, you would have carried the TV over the street and you wouldn't have been scared of them, do you agree with that?

I want you to think carefully back, my information is that there was one Defence Force vehicle on Frikkie Meyer Boulevard.  Is it possible that you are making a mistake, that you only saw one vehicle?
No, it is not a mistake, I saw three vehicles.
Why don't you make mention of the vehicles in your affidavit?  You made an affidavit describing the attack and you don't mention them in your affidavit?
Well, I don't know why it doesn't appear there, but I told my lawyer that I took a TV and I left it on the open veld and the reason why I left it there.
So you are saying, you consulted with your lawyer and your lawyer made a mistake?  Is that what you are saying?
And you also told him you saw three vehicles?
That is an important aspect that is not in your affidavit?  Can you give an explanation why that is left out?
Well, I cannot explain why it does not appear on my affidavit.
I put it to you that you are mistaken, and that all you saw was a single solitary buffel on Frikkie Meyer Boulevard?
And did you see this buffel, what it was doing before you crossed Frikkie Meyer Boulevard?
Well, I don't know what is a buffalo.
Okay, let's call it a suitcase.  Did you see what the suitcase was doing, before it crossed Frikkie Meyer Boulevard?
The first time that I saw this suitcase, it was moving from Cape Gate along the road, towards Vanderbijlpark.  It was moving.
And then it must have turned left in Frikkie Meyer Boulevard because you explained that you saw it in Frikkie Meyer Boulevard.  Do I understand your evidence to be that?

The first time that I saw this vehicle, it was next to the firm and the garage and then it turned left towards Vanderbijlpark.
	They reduced their speed and then they ended up stopping and that is when we crossed the road.
In what direction was the headlights of this vehicle looking, was it in the direction of the group or was it away from the group?
They were facing towards Vanderbijlpark.  They were not facing at us.
So they turned around?  Is that what you are saying, they were looking away from the group, at Vanderbijlpark, towards Vanderbijlpark?
They were not going to Vanderbijlpark, they were just facing towards Vanderbijlpark.
Were they ever facing in your direction, in the direction of the group?
Let me put it this way, only one of them faced in our direction because it was turning around, so the others just reversed.
At what stage was this one, that was facing in your direction, was this while you were crossing Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, is that what you are saying?
And where were the other two that were reversing?  The answer hasn't been interpreted to me Mr Chairman.
He wants to know whether you mean when they were crossing the road?
Would you repeat the answer?  Mr Interpreter, is there a problem there?
The applicant was asking a question whether does he want to know when we were crossing the road, when these two cars were reversing or not?  He is asking the legal representative.
The question is, what were the other two vehicles doing while you were crossing the road?
You referred to the two that were reversing?
That is correct Mr Chairman, I want to know where were these two vehicles that were reversing, while the applicant was crossing the road?
They were at the back, because they were reversing while we were crossing the road, they were next to the robots.
Will you please look at a photograph of the scene, it has been handed in as Exhibit M1.   Do you have the phonograph in front of you?
Do you see there is a road that runs across the photograph, approximately just above point (d) on the left hand side, to point (m) on the right hand side, do you see that?
If you look along that road, you will see at the top of the page, there is a point marked (h), that indicates a foot bridge on Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, do you see that?
Right, is that where the group crossed from Boipatong into kwaMadala?

And I understand your testimony to be that the first time you saw these vehicles, was after the attack, while you were gathering on the eastern side of Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, in that veld between Frikkie Meyer Boulevard and Boipatong, is that correct?
Only after the attack was completed, did you see these vehicles, is that correct?
The first time I saw them, they were there at point (c).
Point (c) is where Unipark Motors is, that is where the Trek garage is?  Is that right?
That is correct.  Point (c) is where the garage is, at the back there, there is a firm.  So the first time I saw them, they were there and then they turned left at the garage.
If you are saying they turned left, does that mean, did they move in that direction along Frikkie Meyer Boulevard in the direction of the foot bridge, is that what you are saying?
So the first time you saw this vehicle, the attack had already been completed.  You were gathering to go to kwaMadala?
Right.  Now, the two vehicles that were reversing, were they reversing in this Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, is that what you are saying?
So were they reversing towards the group, you are saying that the headlights were not facing you, that they were reversing.  Do I make the correct assumption, were they reversing towards the group?
No, they were reversing towards the robot next to the garage.
So were they reversing from the garage towards the robot, is that what you are saying?

They were not reversing from the robot, they were reversing, I don't know how can I explain this.  Let me explain it this way, there at point (e), when you go down with that road, they started reversing from that point towards the robot, until they reached the robot.
So you are saying that they were at point (e) at this stage?
They were not exactly at point (e), but when you move down that road, they reversed from there towards the garage.
Why do you refer to point (e)?

Just to save time, I have been looking at the indication here, what the witness is doing, is extending that line of point (e) right to Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, that is not on Noble Boulevard, but he just uses that as a marker, but he points to Frikkie Meyer, lower down, so you must actually extend that line to Frikkie Meyer.

Do you have a pen, could you ask the witness to please indicate the - on the map, on that Exhibit, the point at which he saw those vehicles?  Show it to Counsel.  Can you have a look at that?  Is that the mark that is almost below (e)?
I understand so Mr Chairman.  Mr Chairman, I understand it to be at the end of the nursery.  You will note that there is a ...

Mr Mazibuka, will you please put a circle on the mark that you have made so that we can see which one it is, there are two x's there.
	Show it to Mr Da Silva first.
Mr Mazibuko, the point that you have marked is on the road, on Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, at the end of the nursery, is that correct?
You testified earlier and I understood your evidence to be that the other two vehicles, the vehicles that were reversing, were reversing from the garage to the robot, is that correct?

They were not reversing from the garage to the robot.  They were reversing from that point, that is where they stopped and one of them, turned around and the two of them reversed from that point that I have already indicated, and they reversed from that point to the garage.

Mr Mazibuko, my information is that immediately after the attack, there were only to use your words, two suitcases available and if necessary I will lead evidence to that effect.
	Aren't you mistaken when you say you saw three vehicles?
No, I did not make a mistake, I saw three.
Yes, there were only two vehicles available from Vaal Commando and only one vehicle was in this vicinity.
Well, I did not see one vehicle.

I don't have any further questions Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR DA SILVA
Yes, thank you.   The time now is approximately half past five.  Ms Tanzer, we intend rising at this stage.  Do you have any objections to commencing your cross-examination tomorrow morning?
None whatsoever, I can prepare Mr Chairman.
Yes.  Yes, thank you.  Just before I forget this point, Mr Da Silva, the witness has been referring to a suitcase and you have been referring to what?
Okay.  Does your, is what you understand to be a buffel, the same thing as what he refers to?
Yes Mr Chairman, my information and my instructions are that a buffel is (indistinct) known in the area, in Boipatong, as a suitcase.  It is one and the same vehicle.
I think you put it to this witness that according to your information, there was one Defence vehicle, buffel, in and around that vicinity?
That is correct, yes Mr Chairman.
Right.  Is there, on your information, is there any indication at what time that was?
I can revert to you tomorrow morning and I will be able to give you an approximation of the time.
Yes, because it may well be that he did see these two motor vehicles, but at some other stage.
Yes, I will do that Mr Chairman.

So will you please be - okay, very well.
	Mr Strydom, after this witness, after this applicant, who do you intend calling?
Tebogo Magubane.  I have been given the assurance that he has arrived in Vereeniging, he is in Vereeniging prison and he will be here tomorrow morning.
Okay.  Mr Da Silva, the Committee has decided to accede to your request that we start tomorrow morning at nine o'clock and finish at five o'clock.
I am indebted to you Mr Chairman.

Yes, very well.  Tomorrow we will commence at nine o'clock, thank you.
COMMITTEE ADJOURNS
